title: 111_hr1378
content: The Act is titled the "Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis Management Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act defines terms related to early childhood education programs, ESEA definitions, and schools, including kindergartens and elementary schools. The Act defines terms related to early childhood education programs, ESEA definitions, and schools, including kindergartens, elementary schools, and secondary schools. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Establishment of voluntary food allergy and anaphylaxis management guidelines. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, must develop voluntary guidelines for managing food allergies and anaphylaxis in schools and early childhood education programs within one year of the Act's enactment. These guidelines will be available for implementation on a voluntary basis by local educational agencies and interested entities. Each individual plan developed under these guidelines will be considered an education record under FERPA. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, must develop voluntary guidelines for managing food allergies and anaphylaxis in schools and early childhood education programs. These guidelines will address parental obligations to provide documentation from their child's physician or nurse supporting a food allergy diagnosis and any risk of anaphylaxis. The guidelines for managing food allergies and anaphylaxis in schools and early childhood education programs include a history of anaphylaxis, prescribed medication, emergency treatment procedures, signs of a reaction, readiness for self-administration, and substitute meals. Individual plans tailored to each child's needs are created in consultation with parents. Individual plans are tailored to each child with a documented risk for anaphylaxis, including self-administration of medication if allowed by state law. Communication strategies with emergency medical services, reducing exposure in school areas, and disseminating information on life-threatening food allergies are also included. The curr_chunk discusses the importance of training school staff to manage life-threatening food allergies, including administering epinephrine when necessary. It also emphasizes the need for a plan in place for managing anaphylaxis during extracurricular activities. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of managing food allergies and anaphylaxis in schools and early childhood education programs, including administering epinephrine and notifying parents. It also mentions the Secretary determining necessary elements for managing these conditions. Preempt State law on students self-administering medication for anaphylaxis. SEC. 4. SCHOOL-BASED FOOD ALLERGY MANAGEMENT GRANTS. The Secretary may award grants to local educational agencies to implement voluntary food allergy and anaphylaxis management guidelines. To be eligible for a grant, a local educational agency must submit an application including assurance of compliance with the guidelines and a description of funded activities. The Secretary may award grants to local educational agencies for implementing food allergy and anaphylaxis management guidelines. The activities funded by the grant include implementing guidelines at schools, informing parents and students, training school staff, and any other activities deemed appropriate by the Secretary. Each local educational agency receiving a grant must provide details on fund usage, monitoring of guideline adoption, and reporting requirements. Grant funds can be used for purchasing materials and supplies to support food allergy and anaphylaxis management guidelines. The management guidelines include training for personnel, educating students on food allergies, outreach to parents, and other activities. Grants can be awarded for up to 2 years, with funding in the second year contingent on a successful program evaluation. The Secretary may not provide grant funding beyond the specified limit. The Secretary limits grant funding to local educational agencies to 2 years. Grants cannot exceed $50,000 annually and priority is given to agencies with high percentages of eligible children. Matching funds are required for grant recipients. The local educational agency receiving the grant must contribute at least 25% of the grant amount in non-Federal funds, which can be cash or in-kind. Federal funds or services subsidized by the Federal Government cannot be included in the non-Federal contribution. Additionally, up to 2% of the grant amount can be used for administrative costs. The local educational agency must provide information on grant spending and implementation of guidelines. Grant funds should supplement, not replace, other funds. $30,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2010. The food allergy and anaphylaxis management guidelines developed by the Secretary are voluntary for local educational agencies. However, the Secretary can enforce implementation as a condition for receiving a grant.
